review_title: TTUHSC is the best work environment ever!
pros: It is the most supportive and flexible environment for employees I have ever worked in, but there is still a high standard of work productivity and service to each other. People actively are kind and there is enough flexibility for managers to run their departments, so it is not bureaucratic and stringent feeling. Plus, we do awesome things for cities and rural communities by educating future providers and actually providing health care,  which makes you feel like you are doing something important everyday.

review_title: Not a bad place to work, use this place as a stepping stone to something better.
pros:
1. Very low stress environment. (There is not much of a rush to do anything, very chill place)
2. Co-workers and other department's personnel are very nice and polite. (People you interact with will treat you kindly)
3. Decent benefits. Lots of time off. (Great work/life balance)
4. Immediate supervisor at the Abilene campus is great, takes care of employees, and is totally worth working for! (One of the best parts of the job)
5. Business casual dress code. (Relaxed dress: Pants and collared shirt)
6. Work place cultural values are pretty nice here. 
7. Hour long lunch break and you can pick the time you take it. (Within reason of course)
8. Not a much travel. (You will be home just about every night)
9. Work parties and holidays are nice here! People around here can cook! (LOL)

Summary of Pros:
The best part of the Safety Officer Job at Texas Tech Abilene, is the feeling of being part of a family work culture. There are lots of good people to be friends with here. I would recommend this job for someone who wants a chill place and has no plans to advance, basically a great place to retire and work.
cons:
1. Safety Services senior management is uncaring. 
2. Senior Management will hire from the outside, before they hire or promote from within, despite what they tell you. (BEWARE: Don't expect to advance within the Safety Service dept., there is rarely an opening, same goes for all the other depts.)
3. Senior management gives very little communication and direction, they are happy to ignore you for the most part. (Until there's a problem. You're pretty much on your own every day. You will need to find something to do every day)
4. With no directions, the work days feel very long. (Everyday drags on)
5. Senior management is difficult to reach when you have an issue. (Replies take a long time. Days to even weeks.)
6. Advancement opportunities are very rare, there is just nowhere to go. (If you are young (below 30) and want to advance your career, Safety Services Dept. is unlikely to help you much)
7. Pay is really low. One of the lowest paying safety jobs in Texas and I got the max the senior management budgeted it for. (BEWARE: It’s just enough to scrape by on, very small raises, if any at all. I got one .29 cent raise in 2 years)
8. You will be the Safety Officer for both Abilene and Dallas campuses. No extra pay and next to no possibility of overtime (Emergency overtime pay only, we never had an emergency in 2 years).
9. Nothing ever happens fast, lots and lots of frustrating bureaucracy and internal politics. (Stuff takes weeks to months to happen. Welcome to a state job)
10. Pay to park on campus. It is optional, and as of 2020 it's $14 a month to park on campus. (Not worth it, you're basically just paying, so Security can eventually ticket you for a mistake and they check the parking lots everyday)
11. You will deal with hazardous waste (bio and chem) nearly every single day. Exposure is very possible. (Lab personnel are not great at packing it up correctly, always check it before accepting it)
12. No official job specific training. (The Safety Manuals, university policies, and the university wide generic online safety trainings is pretty much all you get. Lots of dry reading and you better know it!)
13. Nearly all equipment is either a hand-me down, so old its obsolete, or its missing parts. (Safety dept. is actually working on fixing this, slowly, but surly)


Summary of Cons: 
The worst parts of the Safety Officer Job at Texas Tech Abilene, are the senior management's lack of caring/communication and no advancement. If things continue this way, as they did for me over the course of 2 years, you will be left alone every day to figure out what in the world you're supposed to be doing nearly every day. I would recommend using this place as a stepping stone while looking for something better to do.

review_title: Mediocrity and academic bureaucracy with a healthy mix of petty intra-organizational politics
pros:
As a research assistant (PhD student) in the GSBS, nobody cares what you do, whether you get anything done, or whether or not you even show up to work. If you are lazy, this is the place for you!

This college is a career post-doc mill. For those that just want to get PhDs but never want to embark on their own, this is the college for you. The majority of students go from working as a graduate assistant in their lab, to graduating and working as a post-doc in the same lab. 

If your only ambition is to post-doc in Lubbock Texas doing irrelevant research for the next 15-20 years, this is the college for you!

Don't get me wrong - the other colleges (School of Medicine, Allied Health, Nursing, and Pharm) all value their students - vs. the GSBS, whose only interest is inexpensive labor.
cons:
The apathy and laziness of the faculty and staff is mirrored by the caliber of students that the GSBS admits: almost exclusively under-performing, lazy students preparing for career post-docs.

This college is also an excellent example of why the tenure system is broken. So many unfunded professors with vacant labs that are effectively just taking up space.

job_title: IT Support Technician IV in Lubbock, TX
pros: 8-5 work environment with little extra work outside normal hours of operation.
cons: Wages were fair at initial employment but lack of upward mobility and no raises after multiple years makes staying all the harder. High turnover results in more duties being added to the more stable employees with no added pay incentives. Lastly, some departments are run much more strictly than others, causing a disparity between the lax departments and the stricter ones. Good luck determining in an interview which one you are applying to.

pros: Some of the most uplifting, compassionate, and mission-driven faculty, staff and researchers I’ve ever worked with.  Mostly very respectful and appreciative of each other.
cons: Large institution with not a lot of room for advancement, management is trying to turn things around with more positive culture and organizational change.  Salary will be lower than industry but environment is usually good.  Management does not always remove poor performers - it gets very political.  Pretty typical large and bureaucratic agency.

job_title: Post Doctoral Research Associate in Lubbock, TX
pros: The administration can be speedy.
cons: I was treated very unappreciative, the communication was limited and dysfunctional, I was threatened twice to be fired, the dealings with me very unfair and unreasonable. I moved all the way from Germany there, worked alone in a lab for a supervisor who had not set up the lab, which was non-functional. My supervisor offered to be the guarantor for my apartment. Although I had paid my rent, he was putting unprofessional pressure on me to be removed as a guarantor later. That led to a serious of events that were very inappropriate and resulted in my termination. I did not have the chance to talk to anybody higher up. Because this university is the only one in the city and there is nothing in West Texas within the next 4 hours, they seem to live in a bubble without laws. Do not work there.

job_title: Senior Business Assistant in Amarillo, TX
pros:
Benefits are great, you get the full State ERS Benefits. 
Feeling of accomplishment knowing your helping people
Lots of employee programs to help in times of need
cons:
Work environment can be filled with conflict
People that are selected to lead have no experience in those positions

pros: Unless you work for the Lubbock campus the pros for Permian Basin do not apply
cons: Permian Basin is set in 1950 where women's voices are not heard, and promotions are not given. You are pretty much glued to a seat until given permission to move to even use the restroom most days. Jokes about race, people being handicapped, and women are daily talk, and even when they are reported to HR like they are supposed to be nothing is done about it. It's very sad that a dean has 3 assistants that do nothing all day and cannot help other departments that are struggling. Large turnover due to poor management. BEWARE AND STAY AWAY FROM THIS PLACE. The only way TTUHSC-Permian Basin can ever get on the levels of other institutions is to clean house and start all over.

job_title: Senior Academic Advisor in Lubbock, TX
pros: There were no pros. Do not recommend working for this department.
cons:
Toxic work place. Unrealistic deadlines. Horrible training, always told to look at notes, basically training yourself then getting in trouble for doing it wrong. Always got to work wondering, “what might I get called in for today.” Management plays favorites and bully’s the rest. The list goes on... 
With the high number of turnovers you would think HR would start looking at upper management. They are the problem, not everyone that has been bullied into quitting, or those who up and left.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in El Paso, TX
pros: TTUHSC El Paso is growing, many career advancement opportunities, always learning new things, great benefits
cons: Upper management is not as open and reachable as one would expect from a relatively small health sciences center; not much to offer in terms of perks, such as fitness center and close parking; there isn't a high importance placed on training staff by administrators

pros: Everyone in the School of Nursing is so sweet and caring. The benefits are very nice, especially with TRS matching at 6.8%, I believe. I have a great supervisor and the leadership is great.
cons: Staff is not paid a competitive salary to what they would make in industry, however faculty are. So just be prepared for that. Outside of that, I have not had very many cons.

job_title: Residency Unit Coordinator in Odessa, TX
pros: The Residency Coordinator job is challenging and dynamic.  This position would be great for a self-starter and someone who is proactive.  If you need lots of direction from your supervisor, I do not recommend this position.
cons: I was underpaid for the level of experience I brought to the job.  I found it stressful at first because I wasn't able to get the direction and leadership I needed from my boss.  I taught myself the job and the position.

pros: This is a first-class institution dedicated to scientific research and patient care. They have a great medical/health program and ranked highly among teaching hospitals.
cons: The location of Lubbock is a little far from the next major city, although Lubbock has all the amenities you'd want. It gets hot, but it's a dry heat.

pros: Steady paycheck, free benefits. Met some cool people.
cons: Favoritism abounds, nobody gets along, lots of drama. If you disagree with someone a superior likes, they put a target on your back. Laziness is rewarded, hard work is not. They rely heavily on who you know not what you know. No room for promotions or career growth.

pros: Retirement is good as long as you plan on being there until you are ready to retire. If you are a nurse the hours are good.
cons: It is very stressful and the retirement is good only if you are retiring there after a lot of years. Consider this when taking this job. Read the retirement requirements carefully. e

review_title: Great Place to Work, Learn and Grow
pros: Being involved in a educational environment, you are encouraged to improve your skills, and given the opportunity to do so.   It's constantly growing, and expanding.
cons: It's such a great place to work, nobody quits not leaving much opportunity to advance.  The salaries are lower than the public sector offer doing similar work.

pros: The workplace is very flexible. In general you can decide your work schedule as long as you take care of your business as expected. And people there are very friendly to work with. I love them.
cons: climate is not ideal. Most often we get dusty storms in the spring and winter, which drive us crazy. Sometimes we have to stay at home for the whole day. It was the only thing we hate it.

pros: It's hard to get fired
cons: This company hires people of questionable character, does not pay well and has zero support from administration. On three occasions the same RN came to work drunk and it was ignored by administration even with the medical director being the one to report it.

pros: Good benefits including healthcare, spouse college tuition scholarship.  Good people, occasional trips to conferences covered, including meals and mileage and flight.
cons: The pay is not the best.  Also, upward mobility can be difficult due to limited turnover in higher level positions.

review_title: Not bad for temp job to add skills to resume. Not a career.
job_title: Lead Technician in El Paso, TX
pros: You get out of it what you put into it. Each lab is allowed to run by PI preferences so can be very flexible.
cons: Low pay, little to no job growth potential. Frustrating admin with no supervision or enforcement on how labs are run.

pros: As a state university, the benefits are fantastic. These really should be considered when comparing offered pay to that of private companies, especially if you have, or plan to have a family.
cons: It is hard to receive raises. The best way to increase pay is to move from one department or job to another. This is not discouraged (by most) and somewhat expected.

review_title: Great Benefits, Great Organization, Poor Leadership, No Career Advancement
pros: Great Benefits, Free Healthcare, Great Organization
cons: Poor Management, No career advancement, Poor Management

review_title: Nice place to work, strong values.
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in El Paso, TX
pros: Nice campus with state-of -the-art facilities. nice working environment , strong corporate values , great integration activities, very professional personnel. Cool benefits including comprehensive health insurance.
cons: Positions rely on external funding and once funding runs out, you are out.  Long path to tenure track positions. Although punctual wages are quite low.

job_title: Graduate Athletic Trainer in Lubbock, TX
pros: Large variety of locations for placement and unbelievable amount of knowledge from instructors. The coordinators for clinical rotations are extremely helpful in achieving your goals and ideas for types of learning experiences.
cons: Lubbock, the city is not for me. Some people love it but after growing up outside of Texas, I will prefer it there.

pros: Insane flexibility - Come in late and leave early so long as you get your work done. Free healthcare and quiet atmosphere.
cons: Pay is low side of competitive, Hard to advance for new grads as most people tend to stick around.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in El Paso, TX
pros:
Hard-working employees. 
Paid time off with about 14 paid holidays a year.
Fun organizational events throughout the year.
cons:
Management is less than stellar.
Some higher ups are very entitled.
Micromanagement is huge here. 
Instead of coming directly to you, peers will go straight to management to get you in trouble.

review_title: Texas Tech is a great place to work!
job_title: Patient Services Specialist in Amarillo, TX
pros: Texas Tech is a family oriented place.  At Tech, you make long-lasting friendships and even become a part of a great big Tech family.  Work is rewarding as you get to help many patients.
cons: Some of the organization could use work.

pros: Three great schools with great leadership! The Regional Dean's are all about their employees.  Great benefits and for the majority great coworkers.  Lots of diversity, lots of growth opportunities and recognition.
cons: Upset employees who post lies because someone made them mad and STILL working there!

job_title: IT Support Technician in El Paso, TX
pros: The enviroment and knowledge you can gain by working in the company is great.
cons: I would like it if the pay was more competitive.

pros: Great leadership in the SOM.   Wonderful, caring staff at all levels in the clinics.   Tremendous amout of available resources from the Billing and Coding team.
cons: Salaries could be more in line with other State supported Medical Schools.

pros: Good benefits and flexible hours. Great opportunities for learning and collaborating. Good relationships between labs and research teams. Very understanding with time off.
cons: Pay is not consistent between staff and labs. Horrible cafeteria food. Budget team is not helpful.  Purchasing department needs improvement.

review_title: Very professional and well equipped facilities
pros: There are some of the of the best resources at the Health Sciences Center, which has a great partnership with the University Medical Center, an engine of medicine and research.
cons: Distance from major cities may hamper cooperativity with other hospitals and universities.

pros:
Allows for personal/school work to be done when not busy
You generally know what you're walking into everyday when you go into work
cons:
minimum wage
restrictions on the maximum number of hours you can work (20 hours as student assistants)
some flexibility with scheduling and covering shifts
relaxed friendly enviroment

review_title: Great working opportunity in the field of research
pros: Professional exposure and the research experience, backed up by the professional knowledge and expertise in respective fields, shared between the faculty members, and cutting edge technology and hands on experience.
cons: Long hours doing research, is sometime a big deal

pros: Working at TTUHSC El Paso is a matter of pride. The atmosphere is quite familiar, the city itself is nice and is a good place for conducting research with good guidance.
cons: Pay is too low and expectations for a rise are beyond reality.

job_title: Undergraduate Student Assistant in Lubbock, TX
pros: Friendly people, and good work experience, I enjoy the work. It really gives valuable experience and helps on your CV.
cons: Not enough pay, and the hours in the summer are low, it's something you know going into it but it's still a real issue.

pros: Excellent health, education and vacation benefits.  Nice people to work with. Excellent retirement benefits with the State of Texas
cons:
limited upward mobility, a bad culture of office politics, very clique-ish.
Senior management hires their less qualified friends for junior management positions

review_title: Excellent place to work! Would have liked to have retired from TTUHSC had we not moved to another state.
job_title: Administrative Medical Secretary in Lockport, IL
pros: Wonderful people.  Attitude of excellence throughout institution. Facility of people building up people.
cons: None that I am aware of.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Lubbock, TX
pros:
No lack of mentors if you take the time to look around 
Overall faculty and staff are great
Good administration and commitment to a positive workplace culture as of Spring 2019
cons: No other major universities in the area so collaborative work can be difficult

review_title: Texas Tech University Health Sciences Center is a great place to work
job_title: Lead Network Operations Technician in Lubbock, TX
pros: Good benefits. Great Work/Life Balance. Onsite Cafeteria. Access to University resources. Tuition Assistance available.
cons: Very bureaucratic and top heavy, especially Information Technology. Management wastes money due to bureaucracy.

review_title: Easy going place for medical providers
job_title: Faculty Associate in El Paso, TX
pros: Flexible schedules, time allowed for scholarly activities, great staff/ friendly people.
cons: Bad parking, some of the fringe pay like cell phone allowance is not paid unless you ask for it, reimbursements for business expenses takes 2+ months.

pros: The working hours are good, and the benefits are some of the best around. Affordable health insurance for family also.
cons: Pay leaves much to be desired. Limited advancement opportunities unless you leave your current department. Parking can be a pain.

pros:
Good research program 
lubbock is very inexpensive place to live 
university provides lot of scholarship and fee waiver which is very goo
cons:
Not particularly, No complains so far
I would recommend management to improve library facilities
need more access to journals

job_title: Administrative Assistant in El Paso, TX
pros: All of my coworkers are super friendly. They all have good senses of humor and I'm happy to see them everyday.
cons: Some of the directors think they're a bit more important and entitled than they should be. It gets old pretty quickly.

review_title: Not all it's cracked up to be
pros: Great benefits: Insurance, vacation, sick leave.
cons:
VERY disorganized 
Not employee or student oriented
Focused on upper administration and their salaries

review_title: I am very happy to work in this company

Reason behind to work here.
1. There are great scientist to share some thought
2. There are great resources to help
3. Environmental happyness
cons: 1. I do not have any downsize

Superb work/life balance
Superb manager
Very good work environment
Very nice , knowledgable, and helpful team members
Very good benefits
cons:
Compensation is little less.
The workplace is not at a great location within campus
Lubbock city is isolated from other major cities

pros: great place for a newbie to start a career, freedom to use most of the equipment, good colleagues
cons: stagnant pay, most time goes into experiments but no time to read and no journal clubs

pros: Great healthcare benefits. Excellent retirement, 401K benefits.
cons: Working in a prison environment is not always ideal but not nearly as bad as you think.

review_title: Great experience, but no opportunity for advancement
pros: Excellent benefits including plenty of vacation and sick time, insurance, TRS, and social opportunities
cons: Have to pay for parking, no room for advancement in a lot of positions

pros: Pretty good learning experience, I guess.
cons: Ridiculously bad communication.  My assignment was changed through last minute e-mail on which I was frequently not copied.  Finding about changes by rumor.

pros: The research is good and facilities as needed, one might say even contemporary, ample opportunity and freedom to build your skills and learn
cons: not enough growth in salary or benifits

review_title: Great company, average to poor pay
pros: Excellent Benefits, job security, great work to life balance
cons: State jobs normally equals poor pay. The same can be said for TTUHSC.

review_title: Decent place to work at as a graduate student
pros: Flexible schedule allowing to focus on studies. Good supervisor that does not micromanage.

job_title: Senior Analyst in El Paso, TX
pros: I've been employed for over 4 years. Benefits are great. Hourly positions get entitled to yearly merit increases. Employee perks offered.
cons: Low hour vacation earnings for new employees.

review_title: A good university with graduate school, doing decent medical research.
pros: It is a good school for students. generous to student employees.
cons: It is located in a small city, not big ones.

pros: faculty with strong work ethic
cons: nursing staff salary not competitive with local market

pros: Independent practice. Love my job.
cons: Really nothing bad I can say. My salary is probably a lot less than I could be making in private practice.

pros: Good benefits, generally nice people to work with.

pros:

pros: Good and flexible schedule, Enough hours.

pros: Great work environment, coworkers, benefits, and job.
